CD3F56EAC2F1447CB5CE80B9EC7625BC.description: Provide examples of projects undertaken to restore damaged or destroyed habitats.

056F9651F0074F768A2CF894419CEC22.description: Assess current or potential impacts of a changing climate on a specific representative animal and its habitat.

99232E23A67F4DCA8A56602C702D0971.description: Evaluate the importance of a keystone species in a specific terrestrial ecosystem.

20B1A275444D41B7A8F1E4F173942E9F.description: Discuss the implications of the competitive exclusion principle with respect to animals and plants in an ecosystem, including the introduction of invasive species and the potential for shifting ecozones due to climate change.

9D94FEB85877497F99FD32FC1FDEF872.description: Correlate the range and habitat of various animals with Saskatchewan’s ecozones and ecoregions and identify changes to an animal’s range and habitat due to human activities such as agriculture, mining, oil and gas development, forestry, urbanization and recreation.

AB43E8F25C2A4A0D948B3FC5FE8041C8.description: Relate an organism’s specific adaptations and behaviour to its niche in an ecosystem.

7AB012EC455B45579B3DD041AF02FA50.description: Explain the roles of individuals, governmental and nongovernmental organizations such as the Saskatchewan Prairie Conservation Action Plan, Ducks Unlimited and the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada (COSEWIC), and legislation such as the Species at Risk Act (SARA) in protecting and maintaining habitats and biodiversity.

29B43843F333406BA2E86157B8A8E7F6.description: Examine how habitat management and protection decisions are influenced by the extent to which Indigenous land rights (e.g., custodians of the land versus individual land ownership) are reflected through the spirit and intent of various treaties.

7ED64854B3B64FACACF52E31049C312B.description: Describe examples of First Nations and Métis people’s contributions in recognizing the effects of natural and humancaused changes to habitat on historical migration patterns of animals in Saskatchewan.

2BE24310352B4205B9849A82730EBC0C.description: Justify the need for habitat protection and restoration in terms of biodiversity (e.g., genetic diversity, species diversity and habitat diversity) and resilience within ecosystems both locally and globally.

ED8E1305798044BA88320C9EED17AE23.description: Recognize the need for intact habitat to support animal populations and biodiversity.

443B33E45E4441D5B6FFD4EFA6730F89.description: Assess the impact of agriculture or forestry on a natural ecosystem.

F1C915F315C142F3A4E5863003D6E65D.description: Analyse forestry practices (e.g., selective cutting, clear cutting,  shelterwood system and integrated resource management) in terms of productivity, profitability and environmental stewardship.

90469FF8CA234452BC39F80091C28AF5.description: Assess the economic, environmental and societal impacts of various agriculture practices (e.g., industrial, traditional, subsistence, sustainable agriculture, organic farming, urban agriculture, local food and community supported agriculture).

9A31B51CC5334845981F08D7358C06A6.description: Examine advances in crop science that have influenced the types and yields of agricultural and/or horticultural crops grown in various areas of Saskatchewan.

4E0534D8E36A4E1FB1CA0A56DEDC6950.description: Analyze the relationship between plants and climate change, including plants’ roles in reducing greenhouse gases, as well as potential impacts of climate change on plant growth and distribution.

D1765787C64A4AC7800769772C818E82.description: Identify factors that influence plant pollination and reproduction, including the role of integrated pest management.

918427265D134EABBB82AF9B4753A63D.description: Interpret the relationship between photosynthesis, respiration and net primary productivity.

17F3CA6DA5F64AF19C10B703652C8163.description: Explain how plant morphology and physiology determines the role of plants in an ecosystem (e.g., anchoring soil, filtering air and water, providing shelter for other organisms and providing organic matter to the ecosystem).

34779A78217C4299B726525D7029E030.description: Examine the significance (e.g., medicinal, spiritual, nutritional and shelter) of plants, including tobacco, in First Nations and Métis cultures.

6EEAA15E630E4572A061F230BDDB81AE.description: Discuss the many roles of plants including their roles as providers of ecological goods and services as well as natural capital. (K)

A6CD2556BF8140F783928EC5F5CF19D0.description: Examine the role plants play in an ecosystem, including the ways in which humans use plants.

DD9406333DC8445FAB0585D756F8C568.description: Collaborate with a group of peers to propose a landscaping investigation or action plan concerning an aspect of an urban ecosystem (e.g., rooftop gardens, green walls and green spaces) while ensuring conditions affecting local soil are represented.

5498D754A609414A859CD8249C449822.description: Investigate how various small- and large-scale composting systems such as composting toilets, trench composting, vermicomposting, windrow composting, anaerobic digestion and mechanical biological treatment work to maintain and improve soil quality.

AF8AF33E1576432C81379CD8A585D41F.description: Examine how phenomena such as erosion, desertification and soil pollution, whether natural or human-caused, affect soil productivity and food production.

0BCB85C110B84002B5AD45DEFD038EBA.description: Discuss the role of soil in biogeochemical cycling, including carbon storage and nitrogen fixation, nitrification and denitrification.

472451114AE64A2C891B23EFF9F36FC0.description: Recognize the role and diversity of organisms (e.g., nitrogen fixing bacteria, fungi, mycorrhizae, insects, plants and protists) found within soil environments.

A89D7142A16A4C8FA0925CA96908B32F.description: Research causes and consequences of soil degradation (e.g., wind  and water erosion, salinity and desertification) and mitigation strategies (e.g., conservation tillage, contour farming, grassed waterways and shelterbelts) used to reduce the loss of topsoil.

28B274230F7B440B8FE802F4379AD0D0.description: Collect and analyze soil data (e.g., pH, nitrate, phosphate, potassium, porosity and moisture) using technologies such as sensors and soil test kits safely and effectively.

3BC620DB2AC341349AB3FC9718DF0C29.description: Explain common methods scientists use to sample and monitor soil quality over time.

38B390EB15364243AC26AA747943957D.description: Experiment with different soil mixtures, using black earth, compost, sand, top soil, manure, peat moss, vermiculite, loam and/or sand, to determine their suitability for growing different plant species.

AC5FD95AC638413A951EDC39879F5435.description: Understand the interconnectedness between soil characteristics, ecozones and natural vegetation in Saskatchewan.

AF06C86730D34EEEA122390D5D135536.description: Recognize how the breakdown of parent material through various processes (e.g., weathering, erosion, deposition and decomposition of organisms) results in soil with varying properties (e.g., colour, texture, structure and pH).

124372E568B44D7EB8272F573846D00D.description: Discuss how First Nations and Métis people value soil as an integral component of Mother Earth, including traditional ways of looking after soil.

A8B7F9167A0D413EA0A732353A4C042A.description: Analyze the importance of soils as an integral component of terrestrial ecosystems.

91B6F5D4799743B3917A66A4CF4F84DB.description: Design a system of source water protection for a community`s drinking water recognizing the precautionary principle

AA5526966C6C4B73801B5C84DE2072CA.description: Research advances in technologies such as desalinization plants, water treatment plants and home water filtrations systems, which are designed to maintain and improve water quality.

B2B36D7C93A949CF94354CD0BE19651F.description: Investigate the role of muskeg and moss in water filtration and food preservation for First Nations and Métis and other communities.

D799020EB64C4CACAB61103CCF301688.description: Investigate how human activities (e.g., overfishing, photodegradation of plastic waste, shipping, coastal development and offshore extraction of oil and minerals) impact marine ecosystems (e.g., coral reef degradation, introduction of invasive species and reduced fish populations).

A368AB460DBC44428EA68BD5EB577974.description: Research the sources, effects, and management and mitigation strategies of contaminants such as pathogens, organic matter, heavy metals, sediment, heat, petrochemicals and inorganic chemicals such as pesticides in aquatic and/or marine ecosystems.

C91A07A3B6D04012BD3910A562AEE5A1.description: Analyze the impacts of point source and non-point source pollution on humans and aquatic systems

8C1B79D0C2AA4E128B4D56161C437733.description: Describe the operation and effectiveness of technologies and processes developed to protect drinking water sources locally and globally.

B636EE7EE37A46D7811A2CAB307E2FAA.description: Assess how irrigation projects affect food production, water availability, soil salinization and groundwater.

B839C1E4887D4AD191DEC881C7A53235.description: Examine how individuals, organizations (e.g., watershed associations), First Nations and government agencies (e.g. Saskatchewan Water Security Agency) work to ensure clean and abundant water through producing water regulations and allocation policies.

7B9611D4130140BFB9A063AEC0966616.description: Analyze the rationale for developing and enforcing water quality standards such as the Saskatchewan Surface Water Quality Objectives and the Canadian Water Quality Index and legislation such as the Canada Water Act and the International River Improvements Act.

078B53C5F06441F2BA631B56067476F3.description: Analyze emerging health challenges such as the spread of disease, mercury in fish, blue-green algae and E. coli in drinking water that result from changes to the condition of aquatic systems.

5F2DA1B6145644A4B703BE83A51F9074.description: Assess the importance of maintaining healthy water for humans and the environment.

7771C6EFDE804CDD98D3891C03D152D6.description: Recognize different characteristics of lakes from naturally oligotrophic to eutrophic as well as possible causes (e.g., clearing of land, excessive fertilizer runoff and treatment plants) and consequences of cultural eutrophication.

AA93F89EE3FF415ABAD42196AF7FAE16.description: Describe the benefits of the ecological goods and services provided by riparian zones and wetlands (e.g., marshes, swamps, bogs and fens) in protecting water resources.

8F38497B68F2452FBF0D18F0C4E56119.description: Assess how an integrated watershed management approach can address issues (e.g., water supply, drainage, storm water runoff, habitat protection and water rights) that affect water quality and the health of all living things within a watershed.

F3ACCDD6ADB24B22A2B856B29D9E7362.description: Investigate bacterial content in surface water and compare the presence of coliform bacteria to surface water quality standards following appropriate safety procedures.

AE98A1D390DF40A5BAA080D1008F4205.description: Assess the interdependencies between abiotic (e.g., pH, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, temperature, total dissolved solids, phosphorous, nitrogen, stream flow and biochemical oxygen demand [BOD]) and biotic factors in a functioning aquatic ecosystem.

0A90AC2FAB5F46EEB98F0C023D33FAAF.description: Examine the diversity of life in a specific aquatic ecosystem through water sampling, classifying aquatic biota, assessing biodiversity and calculating a water quality index and/or algal productivity.

FCF91544C4C646EC8CE205BDF8139CFD.description: Measure abiotic factors (e.g., turbidity, temperature, dissolved oxygen and particulates) of an ecosystem using a variety of techniques and technologies (e.g., probe ware, pH paper, Secchi disk, Imhoff settling cone and chemical water quality test kit) effectively and safely

4DD413B9BDFE4ADA8532D8926CB8737B.description: Identify how the presence or absence of traditional medicines can serve as indicators of water body health.

269355B3C9874DFABC5A4516BD4F67C8.description: Explain how to measure the condition of an aquatic ecosystem using chemical factors, physical factors and biological indicators including indicator species, keystone species and invasive species.

65DC4D4301CA4FB1B772C10B5DB0F56E.description: Analyze the function and condition of freshwater aquatic systems such as rivers, streams, lakes, wetlands and watersheds.

99B2B4004FB14763B13872BC07C1A05C.description: Debate the benefits and consequences of public policies (e.g., municipal, provincial or federal) regarding the handling, storage, transportation, treatment and disposal of hazardous waste.

AA55621D06F547E18712B97C7E0D7EC5.description: Investigate advances in technologies and processes (e.g., sewage treatment plants, incineration, composting, engineered landfills and curbside recycling) used for storing, handling and disposing of human and/or livestock waste

84D73D1F2A904A5CB68EE3CDAEFFB396.description: Design and carry out a waste audit, and propose a plan of action for waste reduction and/or diversion based on the findings.

FAFA3A8D34384754B737699D2C8232DA.description: Investigate the waste generated throughout the life cycle of a product.

910FA08966924AE69B22DD16C1F9B16A.description: Describe technologies and processes that have been developed to minimize the impacts of mining, forestry and/or agricultural operations on air, water and soil quality and quantity.

8865B4F4EB6942C8A500F7902EB9E530.description: Analyze benefits and challenges associated with the use and production of fertilizer for food crops necessary to sustain a growing human population.

F34A35B040A34C05968553D2635B0822.description: Assess the impact of factors such as advances in food security and access to medicine that support a growing human population.

D22434E939F840BEAF43B474A5AAF181.description: Discuss the strengths and limitations of models (e.g., I=PAT) that scientists use to quantify the impact of population, consumption, technology and stewardship on the environment.

DA03E51569DC4ED2BC4D1B048881A096.description: Research First Nations and Métis beliefs and practices that demonstrate a sustainable perspective on using resources wisely and minimizing waste.

485EB90BFF8A4AED90542C5C0CEF3F4E.description: Investigate the environmental impact of human population changes over the last century on a specific region or area with respect to resource use, waste generation and pollution.

D1A6BD98531342F38AEAD1907E5CF913.description: Identify factors that have contributed to historical and contemporary trends in human population growth and that may influence future growth.

30025ABBAD8D485FA5A874472695640F.description: Investigate technologies and processes used for mitigating and managing resource use, waste generation and pollution associated with a growing human population.

890D777875E54B76B569BF38F237F956.description: Investigate the adaptation and mitigation strategies developed to minimize the potential impacts of climate change on the agriculture, energy, forestry, transportation and/or tourism sectors in Saskatchewan.

E7B18192E03046EA890D19F8DA08AF87.description: Investigate the adaptation and mitigation strategies developed to minimize the potential impacts of climate change on the agriculture, energy, forestry, transportation and/or tourism sectors in Saskatchewan.

8805A0FB2FE948C390FDAD2C39691276.description: Recognize how phenomena such as El Niño, La Niña and ocean acidification provide evidence of how the effects of climate change on one earth system (i.e., geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and biosphere) can produce effects across other earth systems.

6B8BEC022DB64AA3B7E2CC3524EC6F2D.description: Investigate how climate models simulate important aspects of past and present climate and climate changes, and provide projections about future effects of climate changes with varying degrees of complexity and reliability.

B77CF92B560343559FBA2B11A4E2D81C.description: Interpret climate data (e.g., tables, maps, graphs, visualizations and other representations) to determine climate patterns and trends over specific periods.

746DD629BC6844CB81C7CC151D40DDEB.description: Investigate potential environmental, economic and societal impacts of climate change in Saskatchewan on human health, population distribution and access to water and other resources.

292B7061AD1244E09B98E92EB41BE457.description: Examine the degree to which the scientific community has achieved consensus regarding the reality of anthropogenic climate change.

D2736BACB52E4B22B15724C81F9808C2.description: Identify the contributions of Indigenous knowledge in policy decisions related to climate change.

9833D984057549CFB4252241166C6B91.description: Examine how and why organizations such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), Canadian Centre for Climate Modeling and Analysis and Prairie Adaptation Research Collaborative (PARC) work to provide scientific research related to climate change and its potential environmental and societal implications.

47B34B493B2B4D22B20D20E4A9B258FA.description: Investigate the Arctic as an indicator region of climate change, including the impact on traditional lifestyles of northern peoples, given the general vulnerability to climate change effects at northern versus equatorial latitudes.

CA5CE677426045459412D1ED07BA4A34.description: Examine how different techniques (e.g., satellite imagery, ice core samples and dendrology) provide scientists with a variety of data regarding climate change.

C0A08658D390430393729BEB5061E1C4.description: Examine the types of questions that scientists attempt to answer with respect to Earth’s climate and past, present and potential future climate changes.

9500A69C14154EB18DD19B30BC0D0889.description: Analyze the production, reliability and uses of geoscience data to investigate the effects of a changing climate on society and the environment

1ECD1AC6A3624024B34E67641983F0F7.description: Develop a generalization about the relationship between human population density and human health.

F5CDBA3C34F54D97BFD29EF13A837E5E.description: Investigate whether a personal protective device or substance (e.g., sunscreen, mosquito repellent or protective clothing) is effective in protecting a person from an environmental factor that affects human health.

50CA40D548064630A722EB55C050823E.description: Explain the scientific principles underlying technologies and processes such as air scrubbers, baghouse filters, electrostatic precipitators and catalytic converters that were developed to reduce contaminants in motor vehicle and industrial emissions or to improve indoor air quality.

AFA4775718D5428992A47B6D8EC02641.description: Design and carry out a process to assess indoor or outdoor air quality, using appropriate technologies to collect and analyze data.

AC47D30A25D44A5BA1FBB8C6BFB8AC46.description: Design and carry out a process to assess indoor or outdoor air quality, using appropriate technologies to collect and analyze data.

E75E2D37832A4C00B2DDDCB197E4DEF3.description: Investigate the sources and production of industrial and photochemical smog and identify measures that can be undertaken to mitigate their effects to human health.

3DAA4983A9734D3F9F5C4728C5D003DE.description: Analyze the role of various government regulations (e.g., Air Quality Health Index (AQHI) and the National Ambient Air Quality Objectives (NAAQOs)), and legislation (e.g., Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 and The Clean Air Act in Saskatchewan) in minimizing risks to human health.

91707EBED4904768B718FF9137E98BF9.description: Describe the sources of indoor and outdoor air pollutants such as particulate matter, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, volatile organic chemicals (VOCs), carbon monoxide, lead, tropospheric ozone, sulphuric acid, radon, mold and allergens and their potential effects on human health.

C1A74527D9C24A6B87BF8F4A882C16E9.description: Investigate the role of stratospheric ozone layer depletion as a contributor towards human health issues such as cancers and cataracts.

3AFA8599351B48608F15E1A90E5B3F36.description: Pose questions regarding how human activities and technologies have influenced air quality.

A97E675660E04C5486AFC0B58C1A5435.description: Assess the impact of human activities on indoor and outdoor air quality and the need for regulations and mitigating technologies to minimize risks to human health.

160877351EC14D28B76FB77E078B7003.description: Assess how the assumptions and approximations that are incorporated into a model of a particular environmental system influence the reliability and precision of the model.

B55B368A5C2F485F84BC856741B45B89.description: Discuss the importance of systems thinking (e.g., boundaries, initial conditions, inputs and outputs, feedback loops, energy flows and matter transfers) to understanding environmental issues.

57285706E1F74B3BAAD1992568DE7AAB.description: Investigate how data produced through environmental science can be used in environmental impact assessments, such as those outlined in the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, 2012, to guide projects or policies.

C0CD2DE1B0924286B40C4E52AEF4444D.description: Examine how principles of sustainability (i.e., environmental, economic and social justice) are integral to environmental science.

37386B41808F4D988D25A1FACC20D2E5.description: Outline key events, including the industrial revolution, medical revolution, green revolution (agriculture) and the environmental revolution (stewardship), of the environmental movement and their interrelationships with environmental science.

8CBD696D29EE4908A4363BC5FF15C6BC.description: Differentiate between environmental science and environmental studies, including the types of questions asked, methods used to address those questions and the types of data collected.

FFD07B86E6914A36833B992A04C6E5D0.description: Recognize environmental science as a newly developing field that integrates knowledge, theories, models and processes from other scientific disciplines such as ecology, atmospheric science, biology, chemistry, physics, oceanography, geology and human geography to investigate human impacts on the environment.

8F98D87588ED4F1EB0D7020E62E406B3.description: Recognize essential characteristics of First Nations and Métis worldviews regarding the environment, including the importance of the four elements (i.e., earth, water, wind and fire), a sense of interconnectedness with the environment and respect for Mother Earth.

5E681C9930614AEDB101EED1011917FA.description: Analyze how different worldviews (e.g. anthropocentric, biocentric and ecocentric) are expressed through various environmental action plans or environmental policies developed by individuals, industry, government and nongovernmental organizations and First Nations, Métis and Inuit groups

E277D3891FC3478BAF6CD4581BF792C1.description: Engage in place-based learning to gain a deeper understanding and appreciation of the environment.

C079F821363042A7948969C8121261EF.description: Reflect upon how one’s connection with the environment is influenced by personal experiences and cultural understandings.

047E157EF3AF48BC99C9557A21CB69C6.description: Examine the methods, mindsets and purposes of environmental science.

F94B12482E104E448589670B55A28BA1.description: Construct a tool (e.g., rubric, checklist, self-evaluation form or peer-evaluation form) to assess the process and products involved in a student-directed study.

0542495B06D14A1D9B59D44AE7A70509.description: Share the results of student-directed research through a display, presentation, performance, demonstration, song, game, commercial, fine art representation, video or research paper.

13C41EB744224E9D9FFF15BFE8C505A3.description: Develop materials to support the arguments for and against a position related to an environmental science issue.

17D77388444D40D59F4432ADC55DC211.description: Assemble and reflect on a portfolio that demonstrates an understanding of an environmental science topic of interest to the student.

8AB1E8D2D8DE4E548CA0EBA7FB6522C5.description: Analyze an issue or case study where humans have greatly affected their environment, including a cost-benefit analysis and ethical implications.

A718E8EC946F4D60BBD686378A75EF66.description: Analyze data from sources such as student-developed surveys or research studies, case studies or other statistical methods to make predictions regarding the health of a population and/or ecosystem.

074BA284840C470A936F4A77CCFF5C72.description: Analyze data from sources such as student-developed surveys or research studies, case studies or other statistical methods to make predictions regarding the health of a population and/or ecosystem.

9FF755962E1244E48850E1E25893E018.description: Debate the applicability of William Forster Lloyd’s “tragedy of the commons” to contemporary principles of sustainable development.

4E6F40FE85A540F9982557730551980D.description: Assess the extent to which a global issue (e.g., climate change, water shortages, habitat destruction, invasive species and air pollution) is evident within a local context.

39D1287D78914E70ABEB0E9137DF279C.description: Develop an action plan, including a desired future state, goals, targets, strategies and performance measures, to address a specific environmental issue.

0B493584B21749D3A9769DE7B2F44944.description: Design, construct and evaluate the effectiveness of a device, model or technique that demonstrates the scientific principles underlying a concept related to Environmental Science 20

E45981B87A904152AE37A4AFB2D54B39.description: Develop an environmental impact assessment of a real or hypothetical development.

22E220F940804C79B9339CDC5B04BA21.description: Develop a policy, grounded in environmental science, which addresses an issue of concern to society and/or for the environment.

1B41342AF7B74975BAC5985B8D436EE7.description: Analyze the purpose and benefits of a specific municipal, provincial, territorial or federal policy, legislation, regulation, order, incentive or practice related to the environment and/or sustainability.

B28E205E01DD45E7B2E6E2BD50EAE6B8.description: Carry out an experiment following established scientific protocols to investigate a question of interest related to one or more of the topics of Environmental Science 20. (

E43F0CEDE1D0468C8FA47B1FB96B0A60.description: Design a scientific investigation related to a topic of study in Environmental Science 20 that includes a testable question, a hypothesis, an experimental design that will test the hypothesis and detailed procedures for collecting and analyzing data.

8D6141C11C8C44D2AB933C236FF08C57.description: Create and carry out a plan to explore one or more topics of personal interest relevant to Environmental Science 20 in depth.

ABF0EEDF3B734293B6B60DF80C2DF6B9.description: Use acquired knowledge to develop a plan to attain a job of the student’s interest in the environmental science field.

5384E709FC894920A14C0126F593572B.description: Communicate research findings related to environmental - science occupations through a display, brochure, video, presentation software, website or orally.

E18927F8F42E486294710D0799A824DA.description: Compare the roles and responsibilities of various environmental science professionals as they engage with a specific environmental project.

303C625738E948F8976DD0D77CEA161B.description: Reflect upon personal suitability or non-suitability for a specific environmental -science related occupation considering criteria such as: initial and continuing educational requirements; duties and skills required for this occupation; the work environment, including typical hours and shifts worked and typical locations; current wages received in Saskatchewan and how these compare to the rest of Canada; physical, mental and emotional stresses related to this occupation; workplace hazards and safety considerations; other occupations with which they interact with; professional and/or licensing requirements in Canada and Saskatchewan; and future trends impacting the occupation.

02A18E89F614471DBFF49241AE4F2AE8.description: Examine the roles, responsibilities, educational qualifications and personal and professional qualities common to people involved in environmental-science related jobs.

200C56E5EE574407807093B8F4B3468F.description: Identify which environmental-science related occupations are facing shortages and which are oversubscribed locally, regionally and/or nationally.

D533C13D456449619992960FD0016F4D.description: Explore the connection between topics in Environmental Science 20 and occupations of personal interest.

AED574ACFD3E4590B85E21AA45CBCC78.description: Generate a list of occupations that require a background in environmental science through research and/or participation in events such as a career fair or job shadow.

75E66B0B0FCE41518BE9E11FE9FE4693.description: Analyze and explore environmental science related career paths in Saskatchewan, Canada and the world.
